newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan wants close HK links - negotiator.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan wants close HK links - negotiator.

text.p: Taiwan wants to keep close contacts with Hong Kong after the British colony's July 1 takeover by China, a Taipei negotiator said on Wednesday before leaving for Hong Kong for crucial shipping talks.

Chang Liang-jen, deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, was scheduled to hold talks with Hong Kong Shipowners Association chairman George Chao, Beijing's designated negotiator, in Hong Kong on Friday.

"Cross-strait relations have been severed for more than 40 years," Chang told a news conference, referring to the Taiwan-China rivalry. "But Taiwan-Hong Kong relations have never been interrupted and should not be interrupted.
"The sides should maintain close contacts," he said.

Hong Kong is the channel through which more than US$30 billion worth of Taiwan investments have poured into China since the late 1980s, when a political thaw encouraged expansion of unofficial Taiwan-China ties.
Taiwan has warned of painful consequences if no deal is reached over Taiwan's shipping link with Hong Kong -- including a possible halt to bilateral sailings.
At issue is what flags ships should fly when plying routes between Taiwan and Hong Kong.
Hong Kong-registered ships will fly the Chinese flag above the future Hong Kong flag after China assumes control over the territory on July 1 following 150 years of British rule.

Taipei has said it would welcome ships flying the red five-starred flag of the communist People's Republic of China, but only if Beijing and Hong Kong tolerate Taiwan vessels that flew the flag of the exiled Republic of China.
China regards Taiwan as a renegade province and refuses to recognise the Republic of China, which has ruled the Nationalist redoubt since losing the mainland in a civil war in 1949.
Taiwan, which prefers to maintain the status quo in shipping links with Hong Kong, would like to make as few changes as possible, Chang said.
Taipei has proposed that both Taiwan and Hong Kong ships lower all flags and identify themselves through telex communications before entering each other's waters.
Chang urged his Hong Kong counterparts to be practical.
"The shipping matter should not be politicised," Chang said.
"Trade, investment and transportation links between Taiwan and Hong Kong are mutually beneficial. The Taiwan side will adopt a pragmatic attitude in a shipping link arrangement.
"We hope the Hong Kong side can face the talks with the same attitude."
If both sides could not agree in Hong Kong, a new round of talks would be held in Taipei, Chang added.
Taipei had proposed to host the talks at the end of April. But a Taiwan official accused Beijing of interfering with the talks and prohibiting Hong Kong negotiators from coming to Taiwan.
